proposals.reasoning: Most players expressed concern about stacking both Alice and Bob on such a small first team and specifically preferred a mixed pair like Alice + Diana. Choosing myself (Diana) plus Alice spreads risk, avoids early consensus tunneling on Bob, and gives us a clean informational baseline: if this 2-person mission passes, Alice and I look better; if it fails, suspicion narrows sharply between just the two of us. This aligns with the majority preference in the discussion while maximizing clarity from Mission 1.

votes.comment: Early mission with me included gives strong info either way; no solid reason yet to distrust Diana over others.
Table consensus favors Alice+Diana, and supporting this popular first team keeps my position aligned with the group while still giving us early info.
No evil on the team means a guaranteed success that will make both Alice and Diana look too clean early, which is bad for us long-term.
I know I’m good, so this team is a low-risk way to test Alice and get very clear info from the first mission.
This matches the broad table preference for a split pair and gives strong info either way on a 2-person mission.
Early mission gives valuable info, and opposing a broadly supported, reasonable first team risks drawing unnecessary suspicion.
Fits table consensus and avoids known concerns about pairing Alice with Bob; early 2-person mission gives useful info even if risk isn’t zero.

discussion.content: Since it’s only two people, I’d like to start with players who’ve felt the most transparent so far—right now I’m leaning toward including myself and someone who hasn’t hesitated or overexplained, maybe Bob, to get an early read.

I’m okay being on the first team with you, Alice—early missions are useful info—but I’d also like to hear from a couple quieter players (like Diana or Frank) before we lock anything in, just so we’re not tunneling too fast.
I don’t mind Alice and Bob as a starting pair—early data is valuable—but if people are nervous about that, swapping one of them for someone like Diana could give us a comparison point later.
I’d rather not have both Alice and Bob on such a small first team—I'd be more comfortable with a pair like Alice and me or Bob and me so we get some cleaner info early.
I’d prefer we don’t put *both* Alice and Bob on such a tiny first team—something like Alice + Diana or Bob + Diana feels safer and gives us clearer info without risking stacking the same read.
I’m also a bit wary of stacking Alice and Bob together this early—Alice + Diana or Bob + Diana feels like a better way to spread risk and get clearer info from the first mission.

With only two slots, I’d rather we avoid piling on early “consensus” reads like Bob and instead try a mixed pair like Alice + Diana so we get cleaner info without overcommitting. If that team passes cleanly, we can start building a core from there.

proposals.reasoning: We keep exactly one member of the successful Mission 1 pair (Diana) to preserve some proven reliability without auto-clearing both. We add Grace as a strong new information source who multiple players have mentioned positively, and whose alignment is crucial to learn early. I include myself (Eve) so I can take responsibility for this composition and so the table gets direct info on my alignment as well. This team matches the general consensus structure: one of Alice/Diana plus two fresh players, while aligning with Grace’s own suggested configuration of Diana + Grace + Eve/Charlie and avoiding over-reliance on the same small subset of voices.

votes.comment: Structure (one of Alice/Diana plus two new players) matches earlier consensus and gives strong info; no concrete reason yet to distrust this specific trio more than alternatives.
No evil is guaranteed on this team; as evil I want a lineup that includes me or Charlie to keep sabotage options open and avoid giving good a potentially clean second mission.

This stacks two completely untested players with only one partially trusted member from Mission 1; I’d rather see a team that includes exactly one of Alice/Diana plus one of Bob/Charlie and one quieter player so we’re not risking a mostly-unknown lineup this early.
Includes me plus two untested players in a structure I was already comfortable with; good for info and still relatively safe early at 1–0.
Fits the consensus structure (one of Alice/Diana plus two new players), includes one of the Merlin claims for info, and as a 3-player mission a single fail gives us strong alignment data.
Team keeps exactly one of the M1 pair and adds two fresh players, which fits the info-gathering structure I supported even if the specific names differ from my ideal.

This fits the cautious structure most people wanted: exactly one of the M1 pair plus two new players. We need fresh info, and this lineup spreads it without feeling like it’s being steered by any one bloc.

discussion.content: Given the first mission with me and Diana passed cleanly, I’d be comfortable keeping Diana on the next team, but we should avoid adding more than one completely untested player so evil can’t hide easily.

I agree we shouldn’t auto-clear both Alice and Diana off one clean mission—I'd keep exactly one of them on the next team and add two fresh players, and I’m happy to be one of the new ones if people are comfortable with that.

I’m with Bob that we shouldn’t treat Alice and Diana as a locked-in good pair off a single clean mission—let’s pick just one of them and add two new people, and I’d like to see Bob on this team to get more info.

I’m a bit wary that Bob and Charlie are pushing the same “split Alice and me” plan so hard, so I’d prefer a team of me, one of Bob/Charlie (for info), and someone who hasn’t spoken much yet like Grace.
I don’t want to lock in both Alice and Diana as good yet, but I’d really like at least one of Bob or Grace on this team so we’re testing a new voice alongside exactly one of the Mission 1 pair.

I’m fine keeping exactly one of Alice/Diana for safety, and I slightly prefer Alice plus Bob and Grace so we get two fresh reads without overloading the team with the same voices. If people really distrust that, swapping Bob for Charlie keeps the structure similar while still spreading info.

I’m fine not auto-clearing the Mission 1 pair, but I don’t love the idea of just slotting Bob in because he volunteered—Diana plus me and either Eve or Charlie feels like a cleaner way to get new info without overcomplicating things.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had two clean missions with Diana on both, so she’s our anchor. Consensus in discussion was to reuse exactly one player from the last mission (either Grace or Eve) plus one totally fresh player. I’m choosing Eve from the last team because she was part of the successful 3-person mission and has built some trust, and I’m adding myself (Frank) as the new, untested member so we actually gain information instead of just re-running nearly the same lineup.

votes.comment: Diana and Eve are in the most trusted group from two clean missions; adding a single new player (Frank) follows the consensus structure and keeps the risk reasonable while giving info.
I’d rather not reuse Eve immediately from the last 3-person team—this still leans too heavily on the same core. I’d prefer Diana plus two completely fresh picks to get better info.
We need a mission to contain at least one evil; this reasonably mixed team is likely to include the remaining spy and fits the group’s stated logic, so I don’t want to stand out by rejecting it.
I trust myself, Eve has some earned credit from the clean 3-player mission, and we need to test a fresh player like Frank while still keeping the team mostly safe.

We’re at 2–0, so we should prioritize the safest possible lineup over information. Adding a completely untested Frank introduces unnecessary risk; I’d rather see a team re-using more of the previously clean players instead of mixing in a wild card here.
I’m on the team, and with Diana and Eve both coming from clean missions this gives us strong info either way from a 3-player lineup.

I like Diana and Eve, but adding two untested players in a row (Eve once, Frank now) feels too risky when we’re already up 2–0; I’d rather keep the new slot to someone who isn’t both unproven and self-selected.

discussion.content: Given two clean missions, I’m most comfortable trusting Diana (and obviously myself), but we should add exactly one of the untested players like Bob or Charlie rather than re-using too many from Mission 2 so we don’t give a hidden spy an easy pass again.

I’m okay leaning on Diana’s track record, but I’d really rather not repeat both Grace and Eve again—better to bring in one or two of the completely untested (like me/Charlie/Frank) so we actually learn something from this team.

I’m fine anchoring the team around Diana too, but I think we should mix in *two* fresh faces so we actually get some info—something like Diana plus one of Bob/Frank and one of me/Charlie instead of re-using Grace and Eve together.

I definitely want to be on it again, and I’m mildly confident in Grace and Eve from the clean mission, but I’d prefer a mix like me plus **one** of Grace/Eve and **one** totally new person (Bob/Charlie/Frank) so we both stay safe and actually learn something.
I like anchoring around Diana too, but I’d lean Diana plus **one** of Grace/Bob and **one** totally fresh pick (Charlie or Frank) so we’re still mostly safe while actually learning something new.

I’m fine centering the team on Diana again, but I’d rather not reuse both Grace and Eve—something like Diana plus one of them and one totally untested (Bob/Charlie/me) seems safest while actually giving us info.

I’m on board with centering the team on Diana and reusing exactly one of last mission’s players (either me or Eve), and between the fresh picks I’d slightly lean Charlie over Bob or Frank so we’re not introducing too many wild cards at once.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps Frank off after the only failed mission happened when he was added, and it avoids auto-locking Bob into the core that formed very quickly. Diana has been on two successful missions and only picked up a fail when Frank joined, which makes her look reasonably good, especially without Frank here. Alice and Charlie are broadly trusted and haven’t been on any failed team, and I’ve already been part of a clean mission as well. This lineup uses a mix of players from successful missions, breaks up the full Diana/Eve/Frank trio that produced the fail, and excludes the most suspicious player without overcommitting to Bob as definitely good.

votes.comment: Keeps Frank (most suspicious after Mission 3) off the team, splits up the Diana/Eve/Frank trio, and uses players mostly associated with successful missions while not overcommitting to the Bob core.
Charlie is on the team and I’m off, so evil still has sabotage potential without drawing extra suspicion onto me.
I’m happy to be on a team that keeps Frank off and mixes trusted players from earlier missions; this seems like a solid, lower-risk lineup compared to reusing the last failed core.

Keeps both Eve and Frank (the only new addition to the failed team) off the mission, keeps me plus players only seen on successful teams so far; this is one of the safest plausible lineups from my perspective.
Team fits the consensus to avoid Frank after the fail, keeps the successful Diana/Grace core without the suspicious trio, and Grace (my likely Merlin) is endorsing and on it.

Given I know Diana and Eve are good from Mission 3’s fail, there must be exactly 2 evils among Alice/Bob/Charlie/Grace. This team includes three of those four, so it’s guaranteed to have at least one evil and often two, giving the evil team a strong shot to sabotage and avoid a good auto-win.
Keeps the main suspected player from the failed mission off the team while using a mix of players from successful missions.

discussion.content: Given that the only failed mission happened when Frank was added to a team that previously succeeded, I really don’t want Frank on this one; I’d feel safest with a team like me, Grace, Bob, and Charlie, keeping both Frank and at least one of Diana/Eve off this mission.

I’m very wary of putting Frank back on a team after Mission 3, so I like the idea of keeping him off; Alice/Grace feel safest to me right now, and I’d be fine with a team like Alice, Grace, me, and maybe Charlie.

I’m on board with avoiding Frank for now, and that whole Diana/Eve/Frank trio feels a lot shakier after Mission 3, so a team like Alice, Grace, Bob, and me seems like a reasonable next step. I’d rather not keep reusing the same core that just produced a fail.

Given that I’ve been on all three missions and the only fail happened the moment Frank joined, the cleanest read is that Frank is the problem, not the earlier cores. I’d be most comfortable with a team like me, Alice, Grace, and one of Bob or Charlie.

I’m very happy with an Alice/Grace/Bob core for this mission, and I’d rather add Charlie than go back to the Diana/Eve/Frank group that just produced the fail. Keeping Frank off and not reusing that whole trio feels like the safest way to lock in a fourth success.

I get why people are wary of me after Mission 3, but if you’re clearing the earlier missions as “clean,” remember Diana and Eve have been on every single team so far, including the fail, so I’d rather see a lineup that breaks up that pair entirely this time.

I’m very happy keeping Frank off this one, and I’d slightly rather avoid locking in Bob as “definitely good” just yet, given how fast that core formed. A team like Alice, Charlie, Diana, and me feels like a solid mix that doesn’t lean too hard on any one previous grouping.

proposals.reasoning: I’m excluding Diana because she is the only player on both failed missions, making her the strongest single suspect. I know I’m good, so I include myself. Bob has not been on any mission yet and thus has no direct linkage to either fail; multiple players have converged on wanting him on the final team. From the remaining players, I want to avoid pulling too many from the same failed teams or repeating suspicious pairings. Mission 3’s fail was with [Diana, Eve, Frank]; Mission 4’s fail was with [Alice, Charlie, Diana, Grace]. By choosing Charlie and Eve, we take exactly one additional player from each failed mission (Eve from the third, Charlie from the fourth), while still fully removing Diana—the common element. The Charlie–Eve pair has never been together on a failed team, and this team structure (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Eve) is also the configuration most independently suggested and supported in discussion by multiple players, which further increases its credibility as a good-leaning team.

votes.comment: Diana is the only player on both failed missions and is off this team; this lineup takes just one member from each failed team (Charlie from M4, Eve from M3) plus me and the still-untested Bob, matching the most consistent logical suggestions from discussion and minimizing overlap with known fail patterns.
This team keeps Diana, the only player on both failed missions, off the board and uses a lineup that multiple players converged on as the safest mix for the final quest.
Two evil (Bob and me) are on this team, giving us control over the final mission outcome.

At least one of Eve/Frank and one of Alice/Charlie/Grace must be evil, and Bob is completely untested. The exact team Alice–Bob–Charlie–Eve is being pushed by a bloc that includes at least one confirmed-suspect group (Eve/Frank), and there are consistent worlds where Bob is evil and this team contains 1–3 evils. Too risky for the final mission.

From my perspective I know the fail on Mission 3 came from Diana or Frank, so excluding both of them is crucial. This team (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Eve) does that, keeps the double-fail suspect Diana off, and only really gambles on Bob vs. Grace, with Grace having already been on a failed team with Diana.
I’m not on this mission and can’t see any guaranteed evil on it from my perspective, so it’s too risky to approve as the final team.
Bob is completely untested and too heavily pushed as ‘clean’; putting him on the final mission is unnecessarily risky when we can form a team from more proven players.

discussion.content: Both failed missions had Diana on them, so I really don’t want her on the last team; we should build around me plus Bob and then carefully pick two others who haven’t been paired together on a fail.
I’m fine building a team without Diana this time—having her on both fails is just too much smoke. I’d go Alice, me, plus two from Eve/Frank/Grace who haven’t both been on the same failed team.
I agree Diana’s been on both fails, so I’d strongly keep her off; I’m most comfortable with a team like Alice, Bob, me, and Eve, since Frank and Grace have each been tied to a fail.

I know I look bad for being on both fails, but I’m good, and the math says if you cut me you’re forced to include multiple people from both failed teams; I’d much rather see something like Bob (only on a success), me, Alice, and Frank, since Alice and Frank weren’t together on either fail.
I really want Bob on the final team, and I’m most comfortable with something like Alice, Bob, me, and Charlie so we keep Diana off and avoid repeating the pairings that have already failed.
Given how both fails point hardest at Diana and how clean Bob’s record is, I’d back a team of Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Eve as the safest mix that avoids repeating the sketchiest patterns.

I’m not as sold on Bob being “safe” when he’s actually completely untested so far, and Diana being on both fails is hard to ignore. I’d rather see a team like Alice, Charlie, Eve, and me that keeps both the repeat-fail pattern and the untested wildcard off the table.
